conversations.content: What were the main reasons for the decline in Berkshire Hathaway's operating earnings as a percentage of beginning equity capital in 1982?

The decline was largely due to three factors: a significant deterioration in insurance underwriting results, a considerable expansion of equity capital without corresponding business growth, and our increasing commitment to investments in partially-owned businesses, which don't fully reflect in our reported earnings due to accounting rules.
Why do you think the operating earnings/equity capital percentage is no longer the best yardstick for measuring Berkshire Hathaway's managerial performance?

Honestly, I think it's because the results haven't been great lately. But seriously, our business has evolved, and with more investments in partially-owned businesses, this metric doesn't fully capture our performance. It's a bit like trying to measure a distance with a ruler that's only marked in inches when you need to measure something in feet and inches.
How do accounting earnings differ from economic earnings in the context of GEICO's 1982 performance?

Well, let me tell you - accounting earnings only include the dividends we received from GEICO, which was $3.5 million after tax. On the other hand, economic earnings include all undistributed earnings, which in this case was an additional $23 million that GEICO retained. So, you see, accounting earnings can paint a very different picture from economic reality.
Why do you think the size of one's ownership percentage doesn't determine the value of retained earnings to owners?

It's quite simple, really. If you've owned even a tiny fraction of Berkshire over the past decade, you've still benefited fully from your share of our retained earnings. It's not about how much of the company you own, but how effectively those earnings are used. I mean, owning 100% of a business that doesn't generate much value from its retained earnings isn't going to make you richer than owning a small piece of a business that uses its earnings wisely.
How did Berkshire's share of undistributed 1982 operating earnings from the mentioned companies compare to the total reported earnings?

Our share of undistributed 1982 operating earnings from those companies was well over $40 million, which is actually greater than our total reported earnings of $14 million in dividends received from them. It's a significant difference, and it highlights the importance of looking beyond just the reported earnings.
What advantages do you see in purchasing fractional portions of businesses, as opposed to buying entire companies?

I think the big advantage is that we can select from a wide array of major American corporations, including some really top-notch businesses that might not be available for purchase in their entirety. And we can make these purchases in an auction market, where prices can be quite volatile - sometimes it's like dealing with an army of manic-depressive lemmings, but that volatility can create opportunities for value-oriented investors like ourselves.
What makes you and your team most enthusiastic about investments?

It's the purchase of 100% of good businesses at reasonable prices that really gets us excited. This approach has been a home run for us in the past, and we're always on the lookout for the next great opportunity.
Can you reflect on any major acquisitions made by others in 1982 and how you felt about not being involved?

Looking back at the major acquisitions of 1982, I have to say we felt relief rather than envy that we weren't a part of them. Many of those deals seemed to be driven more by the thrill of the chase than a clear-headed assessment of the consequences. We dodged a bullet by not participating, and in fact, we had our own close call with a large purchase that fell through - and that was a lucky break for us.
What happens to Berkshire's ability to utilize capital effectively in partial-ownership positions if the stock market advances to considerably higher levels?

If the stock market advances to considerably higher levels, our ability to utilize capital effectively in partial-ownership positions will be reduced or eliminated. It's simple: when prices are too high, it's just not smart to buy in, no matter how good the business is.
How did the high stock prices in 1972 affect Berkshire's equity holdings in its insurance subsidiaries?

Well, back in 1972, during that two-tier market mania, our insurance subsidiaries only had $18 million in market value of equities, which was a mere 15% of our insurance company investments. That's a far cry from the 80% it is today. The prices were just absurd, and we couldn't in good conscience put our money into those overpriced stocks.
What does a combined ratio below 100 indicate in the insurance industry?
A combined ratio below 100 indicates an underwriting profit. It's like a report card for insurers - if they can keep their costs below their revenue, they're doing something right.
Why might the underwriting picture deteriorate if the annual gain in industry premiums written falls well below 10%?

Well, it's simple: if premiums aren't growing fast enough, insurers won't be able to keep up with the increasing costs of insured losses, which are driven by things like medical inflation and broader liability concepts. It's like trying to fill a bucket with a small faucet - if the water's leaking out faster than it's coming in, you're going to end up with a problem.
What happens when weak managements are in charge of weak operations in the insurance industry?

Well, I've found that weak managements often resort to weak accounting. It's like trying to prop up an empty sack - it just can't stand upright on its own. They might use obscure accounting and reserving maneuvers to mask the true state of their business, but that's just a temporary fix.
Do you think the insurance industry's underwriting experience will improve in 1983 or 1984 as the conventional wisdom suggests?

No, I disagree with that assessment. The competitive environment has changed significantly, and I think that will prevent the usual cycle of improvement. With substantial over-capacity and commodity-like products, many businesses in the industry are primed for profit troubles, and I don't see that changing anytime soon.
What types of businesses are more likely to face profit troubles?

Businesses in industries with substantial over-capacity and a commodity product are prime candidates for profit troubles. You see, when the product is undifferentiated and the buyer doesn't care who they buy from, it's tough to make a buck.
Can businesses in such industries still do well, and if so, how?

Yes, a few producers can consistently do well if they have a cost advantage that is both wide and sustainable. It's like being the low-cost leader in a race - you can still win even if the overall economics of the industry are unexciting.
What determines long-term profitability in industries with commodity products?

It's quite simple really - the ratio of supply-tight to supply-ample years. If you have more years where supply is tight, you're likely to see better profitability. But, as I've experienced, that ratio can be dismal, and those supply-tight periods can be fleeting, like the one in our textile business that lasted just about a morning.
Why is it easier for the insurance business to create new capacity compared to other industries?

In the insurance business, creating new capacity is as easy as having some capital and an underwriter willing to sign on the dotted line. It's not like manufacturing, where you need to plan and build complicated facilities, which takes a lot of time. Insurance capacity can be created almost instantly, which is a unique aspect of that industry.
How did the insurance industry primarily set prices in the past?

Well, it's quite simple really. In the past, prices were set through negotiations between industry 'bureaus' and state regulators. It was a bit like a dignified haggling process, but instead of competing with each other, companies would negotiate with regulators to set prices that included specific profit allowances.
What happened when insurance companies found their current prices to be unprofitable?

When that occurred, both company managements and state regulators would work together to correct the situation. Essentially, we could price our way to profitability, even if there was substantial over-capacity in the market. It was a pretty predictable and profit-producing system, but those days are behind us now.
What needs to happen for the insurance industry to achieve significantly improved underwriting results?

To see significantly improved underwriting results in the insurance industry, we need a major narrowing of the gap between demand and supply. This means the supply of available insurance coverage must be curtailed, which is more about underwriters being less willing to sign on the dotted line rather than physical plants being shut down.
Why won't poor profit levels lead to a contraction in the supply of insurance coverage?

Poor profit levels will lead to a lot of complaining and blaming, but that's about it. It takes more than just bad profits to get underwriters to curb their enthusiasm for signing new policies. A real contraction in supply requires a change in mindset, not just a reaction to current profit levels.
What happens when a company issues shares to make an acquisition, in terms of the value it gets for its shares?

When a company issues shares to make an acquisition, it can customarily get no higher value set on its shares than the market chooses to grant it. In other words, the company is using its shares as a kind of currency, but that currency is only worth what the market says it's worth, not its full intrinsic value.
Why do managers still go through with acquisitions that involve issuing undervalued shares, despite the potential for value destruction?

Managers often go through with these deals because they have a strong desire for size and action, and they can find ways to rationalize their decisions. They might tell themselves that the company they're buying will be worth more in the future, or they might listen to investment bankers who reassure them that the deal makes sense. As I like to say, don't ask the barber whether you need a haircut - he's got a vested interest in giving you one!
What happens to the ownership interest of existing shareholders when a company issues new shares for an acquisition?

Well, let me tell you, their interest in the company's businesses is automatically reduced. It's like inviting a neighbor to merge his farm into a partnership - your domain may grow, but your family's ownership in both the land and the crops shrinks. In Berkshire's case, if we were to issue shares for a new acquisition, our existing shareholders' interest in great businesses like See's Candy Shops and National Indemnity would be diluted.
Why do you think managers might prioritize expanding their domain over the interests of existing owners?

I think some managers might be more interested in building their own empires than in doing what's best for the owners. As I said, if they want to expand their domain at the expense of owners, they might be better off looking for a job in government - at least there, it's expected that decisions are made for the greater good, not just personal ambition.
What are the three ways to avoid destruction of value for old owners when shares are issued for acquisitions?

Well, I've identified three ways to avoid that destruction of value. First, you can have a true business-value-for-business-value merger, where both parties get a fair shake in terms of intrinsic business value. Second, if the acquirer's stock is selling at or above its intrinsic business value, using that stock as currency can actually enhance the wealth of the acquiring company's owners. And third, while it's not explicitly stated as a separate method, the text implies that having a fair and reasonable exchange, like the Berkshire-Blue Chip combination, can also work in everyone's favor.
Can you explain why using stock as currency in mergers may not always be beneficial to the acquiring company's owners?

Think of it like trading a valuable asset for something that's not worth as much. If the acquirer's stock is overvalued, the owners of the acquired company might get a good deal, but the acquirer's owners could end up losing wealth in the long run. It's like I said, a man isn't charmed if his lawn gets defaced, regardless of whether it's by a small dog or a big one - the damage is still done.
What do you think is the primary focus when calculating dilution in mergers, and do you believe this focus is misplaced?

I think the primary focus is on current earnings per share, which I believe is overdone. This narrow focus can lead to irrational actions by managers, as it doesn't consider the bigger picture of intrinsic business value.
Can a merger that is dilutive in terms of current earnings per share still be value-enhancing for the acquirer?

Yes, that's exactly what I've seen happen. Some mergers that initially dilute current and near-term earnings per share can ultimately prove to be value-enhancing. It's all about considering the many variables that affect intrinsic business value, not just the short-term earnings numbers.
Why do you think selling a portion of a company's assets or shares based on a disadvantageous valuation is not a smart move?

I believe selling a portion of a company's assets or shares at a disadvantageous valuation isn't smart because it's essentially a smaller version of a larger mistake. As I said, a cumulation of small managerial stupidities will produce a major stupidity, not a triumph. It's like consistently making small bets in Las Vegas - over time, those small losses add up and can lead to significant wealth transfers away from you.
Can you explain how the 'giving versus getting' factor works in the context of mergers and acquisitions, using the example of Investment Company X and Y?

The 'giving versus getting' factor is pretty straightforward. In the case of Investment Company X and Y, if X is selling at 50% of its asset value and decides to issue shares to merge with Y, it's essentially trading $2 of its intrinsic value for $1 of Y's intrinsic value. This is a bad deal for X's shareholders, and it's not something that would be allowed by the SEC. The idea is that management and directors should use the same yardstick to measure the fairness of both businesses in a merger or acquisition, to avoid destroying value for the owners of the acquiring company.
What happens to the market valuation of a company when it engages in value-diluting stock issuances?

Well, let me tell you, the market valuation takes a hit. It's like finding a bug in your salad - it doesn't matter if the waiter says it's a one-time mistake, you're still going to think twice about ordering from that restaurant again. Similarly, when a company shows it's willing to dilute its shares, investors get wary and won't pay as much for those assets, even if the management team has great operating talents.
How do current and prospective owners react when management has a record of wealth-destruction through unintelligent share issuances?

They lose trust, plain and simple. If management has shown it's insensitive to the interests of owners, shareholders will suffer from a lower price-to-value ratio for their stock compared to other stocks. It's a long-term consequence, and no amount of assurances from management can quickly undo the damage. Investors will be cautious, and that caution will be reflected in the stock's market value.
What is your approach to issuing shares at Berkshire, and how does it impact the company's market value?

At Berkshire, we're very mindful of how we issue shares. We only issue them if our owners receive in business value as much as we give. Think of it like a trade - we want to make sure both parties get a fair deal. This approach, I believe, is why the market gives us a premium. When managers demonstrate they won't issue shares on unfavorable terms, it shows we're looking out for the owners' interests, and that's valued by the market.
What kind of businesses do you prefer to acquire, and what are the key criteria you look for?

We're quite specific about what we're looking for in an acquisition. First, it's got to be a large purchase - at least $5 million of after-tax earnings. We also want to see consistent earning power, not just promises of future growth. The business should have good returns on equity, minimal debt, and a simple business model that we can understand. And, importantly, the management team should already be in place. We're not looking to fix broken businesses or get into complex technologies. We want solid, well-run companies that can continue to thrive under our ownership.
What were the contributions of Phil Liesche and Ben Rosner to Berkshire's growth?

Phil Liesche and Ben Rosner were two of our managerial stars. Phil, at National Indemnity Company, and Ben, at Associated Retail Stores, made our shareholders a good bit wealthier through their outstanding performance. Phil, along with his predecessor Jack Ringwalt, was instrumental in National Indemnity's success, which has been the most important operation in Berkshire's growth. Ben, on the other hand, hit business home runs for us for fifteen years after selling Associated Retail Stores, demonstrating his care and drive in running the business as if he owned it himself.
What qualities do you look for in managers to ensure Berkshire's continued success?

I look for managers with good character, like Ben and Phil, who run their businesses with the same care and drive as if they personally owned 100% of the company. No rules or incentives are needed to motivate them; their character naturally leads them to make decisions that benefit Berkshire. If we can continue to attract managers like these, I'm confident about Berkshire's future.
